keyTakeAways: A man named Ian Cleary was sentenced to two to four years in prison for a 2013 sexual assault at Gettysburg College, which occurred during winter break.
The assault went unprosecuted for over a decade, and the victim, Shannon Keeler, pursued charges after receiving a Facebook message in 2019 that said 'So I raped you.'
Cleary pleaded guilty to second-degree sexual assault and admitted guilt, remorse, and a long history of mental illness, which influenced the judge to give a sentence below state guidelines.
The case highlights systemic failures in handling campus sexual assault, including delays in prosecution, loss of evidence, and the emotional toll on survivors.
Cleary was extradited from France in 2024 after being detained on a vagrancy charge, which inadvertently led to his capture and prosecution.
Shannon Keeler described the years-long struggle to get justice, noting that evidence was destroyed and the legal system failed her despite her initial efforts to report the crime.
The case underscores the importance of survivor-led advocacy and the need for reform in campus sexual assault policies and prosecution practices.

summaryOfNewsArticle: A man named Ian Cleary was sentenced to two to four years in prison in 2025 for a 2013 sexual assault at Gettysburg College. The assault occurred during winter break when Keeler, an 18-year-old student, was left vulnerable. For over a decade, the case remained unprosecuted due to systemic failures, including lost evidence and prosecutorial reluctance. In 2019, Cleary sent a Facebook message saying 'So I raped you,' prompting Keeler to renew her efforts. After years of legal and logistical challenges, Cleary was extradited from France in 2024, where he had been detained on a vagrancy charge. He pleaded guilty to second-degree sexual assault, and the judge, Senior Judge Kevin Hess, considered his remorse and mental health history in issuing a sentence below state guidelines. Shannon Keeler, the victim, described the emotional and long-term impact of the assault and the failure of the system to protect her. The case underscores broader issues of accountability, survivor advocacy, and reform in how campus sexual assaults are investigated and prosecuted.
title: Man Sentenced to Prison After Facebook Message Saying 'So I Raped You' in 2013 Sexual Assault Case
